I work part-time for a company that writes "junk mail." We have about 300 clients; they're all charitable organizations looking to raise money through donations via direct mail. Contrary to appearances, there're are a lot of rules pertaining how to write junk mail. These rules come from years of testing and subjecting written appeals (or the results of the appeals) to the scrutiny of the scientific method. So, if you get a letter from, say, Save the Ducks Foundation, and it's written as poorly as a 6th grader's diary (that is, it's pathos-driven and written at a 6th grade reading level-<del>all its words are shorter than two syllables; it lacks coherent structure; its points seem random, unconnected to one another, and haphazardly placed; half the sentences end with exclamation points; and there's an excess of bold, underlined, italicized, and all-caps words), it's deliberate. In this line of work, stupid brings in the money. Ugly looking letters have better returns. Anyway, one of the most important rules--and it has two parts-</del> is DON'T use numbers, stats, charts because people tune out the second they see data. Instead, tell a story. Look at your junk mail next time it comes, instead of chucking it--which is what practically everyone does (myself included). If the writer knows what he or she is doing, the letter should start off with an anecdote, a story. (Also notice that the "hard ask;" that is, when they ask you to make a donation of X, or X, or X and so on, is located roughly 3/4 of the way down on the first page. One the second page you'll find a post-script at the bottom (P.S.) In an effective letter, the PS will have another "ask." Of the 2% of people who actually open their junk mail, the majority will immediately turn to the last page and look for a signature.  In most cases, their eyes will move down to the PS, and the PS will actually be the first thing they read. It's all so calculated. My point--which I'm wandering around--is that people want to hear stories. The way to the heart is through stories. There is one problem you seem to miss; it's that anecdotes are personally witnessed data - general data on the other hand is not. When people experience a cold winter, that's something they witnessed themselves; if you show them charts of how it's actually getting warmer on average, you have no connection to the collection of data, and thus distrusting it comes naturally.

e.g. they say, that the outer suns of the galaxy move faster than expected - and thus there must be dark matter to still keep them in orbit around the center; but as long as I don't have personal access to how those calculations were made, it will keep feeling alien to me; there is no matrix of personally witnessed data to imbed this claim into, thus it becomes difficult to just trust the assumption outright; and, besides; how do we measure the distance and mass of other stars, if not by extracting multiple pieces of data from one source of data alone, that is, it's light-magnitude; furthermore, how do I make sure, that they didn't forget about details, like rogue-planets and such, entirely? - how did they quantify smaller black holes possibly swirling around in the milky way in great numbers? (how do you spot a black cat in the dark?) - what about dust and free planetoids and asteroids? - I wasn't there when they were developing their estimations, so I have no connection to the data.

There are so many ways to make wrong assumptions here, that it feels worthy of being mistrusted at least some bit, and science is full of hasty assumptions that became well accepted theories, that later had to be overcome. As long as we don't have a formula yet for how how expansion of space works (an initial kick and then inertia? - that's nothing more than an unscientific assumption! - get real, folks!), how can we rule out, that gravity, in light of that, works differently on a great scale than we might expect?

Much of science is not repeatable and does not even involve experiments or controls in any way, such as most of archaeology, cosmology, or sociology. Some denigrate these sciences as soft as a result; however, these sciences tend to use naturalistic methods with obvious applicability to the systems that they represent; whereas, experiments introduce an environmental artificiality that may limit the applicability of the results to the real world. The myopic arrogance of insisting on repetition and statistical methods, which are not feasible in many cases, denigrates a lot of excellent science. There are two parts to this.

1. There have been situations where Mythbursters have done really ridiculous experiments, like "Does cursing reduce pain" or "Redhead Pain Tolerance". This kind of experiments were really poorly done, you cannot let someone know pain is coming and condition their response to it and then try to use that as a scientific proof of anything. If you are gonna create an experiment of something you have to keep it as natural as possible.

2. As humans we are heavily inclined towards "truth" than fact. When I say truth, I'm referring to the interpretation of facts to create a story. e.g. You see the plumber man sneaking out of your neighbour's house. What you might tell people is that your neighbour's wife is having an affair. Same thing happened with WMD stories about Iraq. Truth fills in the blanks that facts do not. Facts just give the status as it is.

The thing is, stories are fun, so shows like Veritasium and Mythbursters should try as much as possible to embed the facts into the story as possible. For examlple, let your audience know that the experiment was run multiple times. Of course giving statistics would seem boring for most people. I guess a balance has to be struck somehow.

But I think the criticism of Mythbusters is that, to a certain extent, they're trying to educate the public about the scientific method. The conclusions they make aren't supported by a background of "good" science (scare quotes because I don't want to say that MB science is "bad," per se, just that it doesn't do the boring, repetitive stuff that characterizes our best science) so they can't claim to be educating people about established facts. Indeed, the reason they're doing the experiments is because they're novel and interesting, because they're untested. So relying on anecdotes there may give a false impression of what good science is.

And... I'm kind of ok with that. I grew up with MB, and it's one of the things that fostered my love of science today. Sure, it gives a misleading impression of what science is, but many of the things that inspire us aren't good representations of the work they represent. A budding musician may be inspired by the apparently glamorous lifestyle of a rock star, not realizing the hard work and difficulties that go into making music, but that dramatic impression still motivates them to start a band with their friends and study instruments. I see MB like that. They inspire people to love science as a concept, which is important for making actual scientists, or at least science-enthusiasts.

I think the truth is more radical: this video basically implies (though apparently not intentionally) that the role of real science is and must be minimal in public discourse. A story can be told just as well using pseudoscience as real science, and the non-scientist public won't be able to tell the difference. And real science can easily be distorted -- and often is -- when translating it into story form for consumption by the general public. I would go even further: since scientists themselves are human, and since the biases discussed here are built into human nature, when doing science scientists are also subject to biases that make stories more convincing than data -- and all the more when scientists try to communicate their findings to other scientists. Of course science has safeguards against this kind of distortion, but as history shows, the safeguards often fail, and a convincing scientific-sounding story can often trump real data even in the minds of scientists.

You make a good point Derek, but I think there is middle ground to be had here. For example, I would not equate what MythBusters does with your channel beyond the surface. You are a trained scientist, telling a story about (mostly) well understood scientific fact through experiments, street chats and so on. Your facts are grounded, usually focus on a single bit of science and you craft a story about that existing science that explains how, why, and why we should care.

Contrast the MythBusters, who start with the sensational and try to build something vaguely sciency around it. They're coming at it with the sensation first - they are movie prop guys after all - and proper science goes out the window. For some things like 'can a blind person drive a car', a mere existence proof is fine, but for questions like "do we only use 30% of our brains" they show a fundamental misunderstanding of science, and even of the technology they use to show their pseudo-science, and come to a conclusion that actual scientists would take issue with.

Part of the problem is just one of framing - they sell themselves as a science show, but then proceed to make grand conjecture about the meaning of the data they collected from their limited (and often poorly designed) experiments. The content of the show wouldn't really have to change all that much for people to be much happier with it, I think. Speaking like scientists (add qualifiers when things are unknown, speak to the limitations of what they've learned, and avoid the pigeonholing of results into 3 categories) would go a long way to increasing their credibility.

Pseudoscience is dangerous. I don't have a problem with communicating actual science in anecdotes, in fact I find your communication style very engaging and fresh, but if we're going to accept that we do need to speak out about the faults of shows like MythBusters, as I think they do harm to the public perception of science and the public's ability to tell psuedscience and real science apart.

This is why I like writing fiction and aspire to be a novel writer. Learning about how much of an effect entertainment media has on us and culture (thus consequently on us)... I enjoyed studying and running studies, but I think stories serve much better messengers of information and ideas than data and facts do.

I think Mythbusters did exactly what they needed to do. If you are just trying to establish IF something COULD happen, you only need one successful result. It isn't necessary to run multiple experiments if you get the desired result on attempt one.
The scientific method in its entirety is not needed if you are trying to determine if you can ricochet a bullet off of a cinder block and mange to do so on your first attempt. Especially if that attempt is captured on video, preferably at high speed.
One successful attempt is a proof of concept, and that is enough to validate if something is possible. Since Mythbusters was basically a "proof of concept" show, they only needed to show the proof of concept, or reasonable failed attempts to create a proof.

Yet some science can be done with a single experiment, and most cannot; Another distinction I've never seen made on Mythbusters (I don't know about Veritasium as I haven't watched enough). Secondly, it isn't that showing the people a single statistically not-significant result isn't helpful for science, it's that it's important to state that when trying to educate people about science. You don't have to do it every show, but when given the opportunity a responsible scientist has to say "This looks like strong evidence that our theory is correct / incorrect. Obviously if we were to want to actually prove this Myth / Theory / Social Observation, we'd have to do many repetitions and analysis, etc...". And then occasionally explain why this is the case. It probably isn't good TV, but it's crucial science education if you're going to call it science education.

I'm in the camp that Mythbusters often does a disservice to science education by leaving out the seemingly unglamorous parts of science....which are often the very parts that are crucial to doing actual science as opposed to something in-between science and the dangerous web of human inductive qualities. People are naturally prone to all sorts of biases and fallacious thinking, and unless a program actually addresses this head on it seems ripe for misunderstanding by the layperson.

In your story about the helping experiments, in the second experiment the scientists chose to show the students the two cases of people who did not help. However, it makes a lot of sense to assume that had they shown two (or more) cases of people that did help or one that did and one that didn't, the subsequent estimation of the helpers vs. non helpers ratio by the students would have been very different. What I'm trying to say is that the people who chose what side of reality to expose via their stories have a lot of control over the beliefs of the masses. This is, of course, nothing new. Now, in the case of the Mythbusters, we don't really know much about their "method", e.g. how rigorous it is. So it is entirely possible that because they mostly perform their experiments a very limited number of times, and don't necessarily take all variables into account, some errors (most hopefully inadvertent) sometimes sneak into the results that they then show us. And since no scientific method is employed, we can't really safely assume that what we see is 100% accurate. There must be some margin of error there. The question is, how big. And this is important, because like I just said, storytellers like these do shape our beliefs, and often in some very profound ways.

It's more than merely a story, it's about the purpose of the data. Accepting wether something is true or right isn't something that we humans generally do based on wether it's factually compelling by itself, i.e. the how-aspect, but rather we tend to accept things that gives meaning to the world at large as well to our actions, aspirations and inner beings, i.e. the why-aspect. When emotion takes over, this sentiment becomes over-bloated and you tend to twist facts so they fit with your sentiment, you lie to yourself and others to fit your agenda, or you simply acknowledge the facts but yet act beside it. When there's no emotion at all, the reason for accepting or learning something is gone (for a human anyway) you don't feel the need for it, and the purpose of the data in relation to you is null and void despite its factuality. Your heart, your emotions, are the things that drive you to and away from something, and your reasoning and logical cababilities, your mind, are the things that steer that drive. When emotion takes over, you simply drive without direction (maniac, fanatics, people that act on emotion), and when there's no emotion at all you can steer all you want but it'll get you nowhere, no matter how smart you might be (depressed people, people feeling they have no purpose, the opposite of a maniac). This is why balance of the two is good, this is why a story, a reason and purpose accompanying your cold hard data, is important. I don't encourage lying in any instance besides maybe in extreme cases, but there are always several ways to look at facts and data and how they relate to you and the world around you, so if you're going to relate something try to sell it.
